newsitem.title: UK: Ldn gold fixes touch off, silver keyed to options.
newsitem.headline: Ldn gold fixes touch off, silver keyed to options.

text.p: Precious metals prices were steady on Friday but dealers were preparing for a further reaction to the sharp upward correction which shook the markets earlier in this week.
Several were bullish for silver but the short term outlook for gold, platinum and palladium was less unanimous, according to dealer comments.
"The accusing finger is pointing at gold. It is no where near out of its bear market yet," one dealer said.
Even so gold fixed at $342.50, just 15 cents off the previous fix. It closed on Thursday at $341.60/$342.10.
Silver appeared to have shaken itself free of gold's bearish tone, witness the declining gold-silver ratio which was around 67 on Thursday against 76 at the beginning of the year.
"The big question mark today is the expiry of the Comex options," one dealer said.
Big positions were out on the $5.00 puts but open interest was even heavier on the March $5.25 calls, dealers said.
"A close on silver anywhere around $5.20 today could be very interesting," a dealer said. "They could go for the calls which has happened before ahead of a U.S holday," he added.
Comex silver is closing at 1305 EST (1805 GMT) today ahead of the President's Day holiday on Monday.
The option expiry will remain at the usual time of 1930 GMT, dealers said.
Silver was indicated at $5.15/$5.17 up two cents.
Gold attracted some buying from Swiss dealers on Friday morning but dealers said it had to get through $347/$348 to show that it was a "buy" again.
"The funds are still in a bind," a dealer said.
"They have taken some profits from their short positions but if the price falls, they will re-establish shorts," he said.
There was no market impact from a Belgian central bank governor comment that no further gold sales were planned.
Platinum and palladium were both steady but the announcement Russia and Japan will start export contracts talks next month could impact prices, some dealers said.
"It might take time for the specs to realise what has happened," one platinum group metals dealer said.
But another said both metals "had been an accident waiting to happen" on the upside given their fundamental strength.
Platinum was at $366.25/$367.25 down $0.25 and palladium at $136.50/$137.50 down $0.50. --Brian Spoors London Newsroom +44 171 542 8058
